awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Optimizing learning from chemistry simulations: Comparing attention allocation and learning outcomes for assignments with and without instructor screencasts
awd_abstract_narration:
Many college students struggle with learning chemistry, in part due to the inherent difficulty of visualizing and developing mental models of molecular level particle interactions that they cannot directly observe. To help students connect these molecular level particle behaviors with what they can observe at the macroscopic level, educators have developed computer-based simulations. Simulations of chemical systems allow students to observe scientific models of what happens at the molecular level when they change different variables. Such simulations are increasingly being incorporated into high school and college courses as they have been shown to positively impact students' conceptual understanding of chemistry. However, the research also indicates that students may misinterpret certain aspects of simulations and thus develop some incorrect ideas. This is a particularly important consideration with the increased popularity of online, blended, and flipped courses that use simulations to aid student learning outside of the classroom. A possible way to address this issue is to incorporate screencasts that consist of videos in which an instructor demonstrates how to use the simulations, focusing students on key features of the simulation environments and helping them interpret aspects of the simulations. By comparing students' understanding of key chemistry concepts before and after they complete such simulation-based assignments, as well as the ways in which students use different online resources, the project team will identify effective ways for students to use chemistry simulations outside of the classroom. The instructional materials developed by the project team - including guided assignments and screencasts to be used with chemistry simulations - will also be made freely available online.

The primary objectives of this Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE:EHR) Exploration & Design project are to (1) develop a set of simulation-based assignments and associated screencasts using research-based design practices; (2) assess and compare student attention allocation and learning gains from the online resources via the different active learning methods (guided use of simulations and instructor-led screencasts); and (3) disseminate the materials and methods developed to chemistry instructors. To accomplish these goals, scaffolded assignments will be developed, to be used with pre-existing chemistry simulations, to focus students on attaining key learning goals common to many general chemistry courses. These assignments will be used as the basis for developing associated screencasts. An iterative design process will be used to develop high quality, validated materials. The project team will then compare student use of simulations with and without the instructor-led screencasts. In both conditions, students will work independently outside of class time to complete simulation-based assignments. In one condition (no screencast), students will complete an assignment in which written instructions guide them in manipulating the simulation. A second group of matched students will complete the same assignment by watching a screencast and manipulating the simulation. Eye tracking studies will be employed to better understand how students interact with the simulations and screencasts, how students use the resources to address questions in the assignments, and how students allocate their attention while completing the assignments. Student learning will be assessed through analyses of pre-/post-test gains; answers to open-ended questions; and near transfer tasks that will involve drawing molecular-level representations, producing graphs, or interpreting data. Research findings, and associated instructional materials developed, are expected to inform chemistry instructors regarding how to optimize student learning from simulations of molecular-level phenomena.

por.por_cntn:
In chemistry there has been increased production of quality simulations that allow students to visualize phenomena at the particulate level (something we cannot see) and make connections between this and the macroscopic level (what we can see with our eyes). This project explored how to best structure learning activities to support students in using simulations on their own, outside of a classroom environment, to understand key chemistry concepts. We used an iterative model to develop scaffolded assignments that focus students on using a simulation to meet key learning goals, and developed matched instructor-led screen capture videos (screencasts) that step students through the same simulations. We evaluated student learning by measuring gains from pretest to matched follow-up, near-transfer questions that included drawing/interpreting molecular-level representations or graphs. We also used eye-tracking to try to identify differences in the ways that students interact with simulations as compared to screencasts. Through this project we identified a number of best practices in assignment design that can help support the development of online instructional materials. These lessons are particularly relevant for classrooms that adopt a flipped class model, where students do activities to introduce them to a topic prior to class and then engage in the more challenging application problems in class. 

 

Intellectual Merit

This project developed and studied instructional materials supporting the use of six different simulations focused on six different introductory level chemistry concepts; Atomic Interactions, Solubility, Gas Laws, Kinetics, Equilibrium, and Acids. The lessons learned were used to create instructional materials for two more topics; the Photoelectric Effect and Atomic Emissions. In comparing the benefits of having the students actively use a simulation on their own in a guided fashion compared to watching a screencast video of an expert using the simulation (while also answering questions as they watch), we consistently found that although both approaches led to learning gains with a large effect size, the students watching the screencast showed learning gains that were as good or better than students using the simulation on their own. Further, the screencast allowed for the incorporation of additional content or the juxtaposition of images in a way that is not possible for students using the simulation. It is notable that this research compared two different active learning approaches to determine which is better, rather than making a comparison to a more passive learning experience as is very common. Further, although the students do show very good learning gains, these activities were specifically designed to be an introduction to a topic and to provide an instructor with a jumping off place for further in-class instruction. The study results for five of the topics have been published and a summative publication is in preparation. Each individual study paper addresses specific topic related challenges that the students encountered and, where evident, how to help address them.

 

Broader Impacts

This work has had significant impacts on students. Each year upward of 1000 students have been directly impacted at the two primary institutions involved in the development of the project. Further, all of the materials are available on the ChemSims.com website and are freely accessible. All of the videos are available on a dedicated YouTube Channel and have nearly 40K views across the set of videos. These views come from a wide range of localities that go beyond the home institutions for the project. The project has also supported many undergraduate students in research, two of whom are now pursuing graduate degrees in chemistry education research and one is a high school chemistry teacher.

In considering the research impacts, even though this work was done in the context of a general chemistry course, the lessons learned about developing online materials are applicable to other subdisciplines of chemistry and other STEM fields. Such online instructional materials are important in helping to support a student population growing in diversity. By allowing students to initially interact with content outside of the classroom, these materials provide students with the opportunity to actively engage with the content at a pace and for the length of time that they need. This helps to make STEM classrooms a place where all students can more readily succeed, rather than just those who have had the strongest prior chemistry instruction. By removing the time barrier that a synchronous class presents, it is no longer only those who get it quickly that can meaningfully contribute to the class.
